results.title: L.A.: as suggested by the art of Edward Ruscha
results.creator_credit: Gary Conklin and Gary Conklin Films
results.brief_description: Edward Ruscha’s paintings, drawings and photographs are the point of departure for this impressionistic study of Los Angeles’ buildings, apartment houses, palm trees, swimming pools, cars and signs, enhanced by the city’s unique winter light. Features music by Gershwin, Django Reinhardt, Eric Satie, Czerny, M. Lecudna. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: L'homme Au Chapeau Rond
results.brief_description:
When his wife Nathalie dies, Nicolas, a former judge, hits the bottle. His mood becomes even grimmer when he learns that his daughter Lisa is in fact the result of Nathalie’s affair with Michel. One night, Nicolas approaches Michel with his revelations and Michel promises to look after the child. But soon after the child is despatched to the country and the two men resume their favorite game: womanising.

Credits: Director, Pierre Billon ; writers, Charles Spaak, Pierre Brive ; photography, Nicolas Toporkoff ; music, Maurice Thiriet ; art direction, Georges Wakhevitch.
Cast: Raimu, Aime Clariond, Lucy Valnor, Gisele Casadessus, Louis Seigner, Jane Marken, Micheline Boudet, France Delahalle.

results.title: L'enfant Invisible = the Invisible Child
results.brief_description:
A young boy is enjoying a pleasant holiday in a beautiful villa by the sea. One day, he meets a young transparent girl, who only he can see and starts playing with her.

Credits: Director: Andre Lindon ; writer, Andre Lindon ; music, Ronan Girre, Jean-Jacques Rulhmann ; animators, Andre Lindon, Muriel Petit, Mickael Volaris.

results.title: L'Ecole Buissonniere = I Have a New Master
results.creator_credit: Jean-Paul Le Chanois, Pierre Corti and Pierre Laurent
results.brief_description:
At the end of WWI, Pascal Laurent, a young teacher, is sent to replace a retiring teacher in a small village of Provence. Pascal is keen on replacing the old authoritarian method of education with a new pedagogy. The children are soon won over, but Pascal’s unorthodox methods meet with the resistance from both his superiors and his students’ parents.

Credits: Producer, Pierre Corti, Pierre Laurent ; director, Jean-Paul Le Chanois ; writer, Jean-Paul Le Chanois ; photography, Marc Fossard, Maurice Pecqueux, Andre Dumaitre ; music, Joseph Kosma.
Cast: Bernard Blier, Juliette Faber, Edouard Delmont, Marcel Maupi, Edmond Ardisson, Henri Poupon, Gaston Modot, Lucien Callamand.

results.title: L'associe = the Associate
results.brief_description:
Julien Pardot, a rather dull corporate executive invents an ‘assistant’, the dynamic, go-getting ‘Mr. Davis’ on whom all the important decisions depend. Pretending to be Mr. Davis’ intermediary, Pardot at last makes it big in the business world. A crisis develops when Pardot’s investors demand to meet Mr. Davis in person—and when several young ladies show up, claiming to be the mothers of Mr. Davis’ children. Re-made as ‘The Associate’ (1996), with Whoopie Goldberg. Both are a re-makes of the 1939 film ‘The Mysterious Mr. Davis’ directed by Claude Autant-Lara with a cast of British actors, including Alastair Sim.

Credits: Producer, Simone Allouche ; director, Rene Gainville ; writers, Rene Gainville, Jean-Claude Carriere ; photography, Etienne Szabo ; music, Michel Bernholc, Mort Schuman.
Cast: Michel Serrault, Claudine Auger, Catherine Alric, Judith Magre, Henri Virlojeux, Mathieu Carriere.

results.title: L'alibi = the Alibi
results.brief_description:
A Parisian dance hostess, blackmailed into providing an alibi for a murderer falls in love with a secret police agent sent to win her trust. Other thrillers of the period were as sharply directed and written, but few had the inestimable advantage of the sparks between Stroheim’s killer and Jouvet’s police chief. ‘L’alibi’ is stylistically and thematically the closest of his [Chenal] films to the work of Carne and Prevert, he all but abandoned his habitual moving camera, while multiplying (studio shot) expressionistic effects of lighting and composition. Chenal has the dubious distinction of being the major filmmaker of the decade (1930s) most thoroughly forgotten by the film community after WWII for reason from which prejudice may not, perhaps, be excluded.” Reference: Alan Williams. “Republic of Images: a history of French filmmaking”. Harvard University Press, 1992.

Credits: Producer, Joseph Nash ; director, Pierre Chenal ; writers, Marcel Achard, Jacques Companeez, H. Juttke ; photography, Ted Pahle ; music, Georges Auric.
Cast: Louis Jouvet, Erich von Stroheim, Albert Prejean, Jany Holt, Margo Lion, Max Dalban, Maurice Bacquet, Roger Blin, Florence Marly, Margo Lion.

results.title: L'age Ingrat = that Tender Age
results.creator_credit: Gilles Grangier and Roger De Broin
results.brief_description:
Marie and Antoine are two students engaged to be married. Antoine’s parents, who live in the south of France, invite Marie’s parents to spend time with them and become acquainted. The two future fathers-in-law slowly become friends before a lover’s quarrel between their children threatens to jeopardize the upcoming marriage of Antoine and Marie.

Credits: Producer, Roger de Broin ; director, Gilles Grangier ; writers, Pascal Jardin, Claude Sautet, Gilles Grangier ; photography, Robert Le Febvre ; music, Georges Delerue.
Cast: Marie Dubois, Fernandel, Franck Fernandel, Jean Gabin, Paulette Dubost, Noel Roquevert.

results.title: Kuumba: Simon's new sound
results.creator_credit: Nguzo Saba, Carol Munday Lawrence and Nguzo Saba Films
results.brief_description: Animated film about a young boy living in Trinidad who experiments with various sounds to create an instrument to play in the Mardi Gras. Shows his success in fabricating a steel drum from the bottom of an oil drum. Written by Joel Dreyfuss, designed and animated by Robert Bloomberg and Jane Aaron, narrated by Lawrence Andrews, Lucille Arnold, Pamela Franco and Opal Palmer. Music by ‘The Louis Arnold Steel Drummers’.
